content_goals: Provide a minimal viable content set for BTY Arena: fundamentals, simulations, and recovery check.
Keep all items short, actionable, and repeatable.
Use observational language only; avoid emotional or diagnostic labels.
Align with BTY Arena 7-step simulation and arena program structures.

pack_list.title: Fundamental Arena 1 Set
pack_list.intent: First set of situation–role–option items for staff-level Arena; builds pause-before-react and team-signal reflection.

pack_list.title: Simulation 10
pack_list.intent: Ten scenario-based simulations for the 7-step flow; practice observable choices and outcomes without judgment.

pack_list.title: Recovery Quick Check (5 items)
pack_list.intent: Short, repeatable prompts for post-run or daily recovery; notice and name only, no diagnosis.

fundamental_arena_1.title: Fundamental Arena 1
fundamental_arena_1.description: Staff-level situations with clear options and observable outcomes. Use for Arena program level S1 or equivalent.

items.situation: Patient has been waiting 20 minutes and asks when they will be seen.

options.label: Say you are busy and will be with them soon.
Acknowledge the wait and give an estimated time.
Say nothing and continue current task.

immediate_outcome.A: Tension may remain; patient may repeat the question.
immediate_outcome.B: Patient often settles; expectation is set.
immediate_outcome.C: Uncertainty may continue; patient may escalate or leave.

items.team_signal: How does our team respond when the schedule is behind?

items.situation: Insurance verification from SSO is delayed and check-in cannot be completed.

options.label: Tell the patient that SSO is slow.
Note it internally and inform the office manager.
Explain to the patient that verification is in progress and give a short update.

immediate_outcome.A: Blame is placed on another team; patient hears internal conflict.
immediate_outcome.B: Issue is escalated; patient is not yet informed.
immediate_outcome.C: Patient receives a clear, neutral explanation; trust is maintained.

items.team_signal: Where does our team place responsibility when handoffs are delayed?

items.situation: A colleague is upset about a schedule change and speaks sharply.

options.label: Pause, then restate what you heard and ask what they need.

immediate_outcome.A: Tension can rise; exchange may continue.
immediate_outcome.B: Emotion is named; next step can be chosen.
immediate_outcome.C: Conflict stops for now; the other person may feel unheard.

items.team_signal: How does our team respond when someone is stressed?

items.situation: Patient questions the amount due and says it is higher than expected.

options.label: Walk through the breakdown of charges.
Send the patient to the office manager immediately.

immediate_outcome.A: Patient may feel dismissed; question may persist.
immediate_outcome.B: Patient can see the basis for the amount; clarity often reduces conflict.
immediate_outcome.C: Responsibility shifts; patient may feel passed around.

items.team_signal: How does our team explain financial information?

items.situation: Two patients are booked in the same slot by mistake.

options.label: Tell one patient they have to reschedule.
Check with the clinical lead and then offer options to both.
Proceed and hope to fit both in.

immediate_outcome.A: One patient is inconvenienced; no shared ownership.
immediate_outcome.B: Clinical capacity is respected; both patients get a clear path.
immediate_outcome.C: Schedule may become more chaotic; expectations are unclear.

items.team_signal: How does our team correct scheduling errors?

simulation_10.title: Simulation 10
simulation_10.description: Ten scenarios for the 7-step simulation. Choices and results are described in observable, non-judgmental terms.

scenarios.title: Patient Declines Treatment After Hearing Cost
scenarios.context: A patient needs recommended treatment. After hearing the cost, they say they cannot do it. You notice concern for their health and a pull to persuade. The moment is whether to push for treatment or slow down and explore what would need to change.

choices.label: Emphasize the risks of not treating and recommend they proceed.
choices.result: The patient may feel pressure. Trust may be affected.
choices.microInsight: Pushing when cost is the barrier often reduces return.

choices.label: Pause and ask what would need to change for treatment to feel possible.
choices.result: The patient may share payment or timing concerns. Next steps can be aligned without pressure.
choices.microInsight: Asking uncovers the real obstacle.

choices.label: Offer to phase treatment and start with the most critical part.
choices.result: The patient may agree to a first phase. Flexibility communicates value.
choices.microInsight: Phasing can bridge need and constraints.

choices.label: Give a brochure and suggest they think about it.
choices.result: The patient may not return. The chance to explore barriers was not taken.
choices.microInsight: Deferring rarely builds trust or a path forward.

scenarios.title: Schedule Is Double-Booked
scenarios.context: The schedule shows two high-production procedures at the same time. The day cannot run as planned. You notice stress and a pull to blame the person who booked. The moment is how you address the error—in front of others or in private.

choices.label: Ask in front of the team who did the booking.
choices.result: The booker may feel shamed. Future errors may be hidden.
choices.microInsight: Public blame often reduces reporting.

choices.label: Meet privately with the front desk lead and fix the day together.
choices.result: The day is corrected without shaming. The lead can own the fix. Trust is preserved.
choices.microInsight: Private accountability supports systems.

choices.label: Take the heat for the team and say you will manage; discuss later.
choices.result: The day runs without public blame. Follow-up is needed to address cause.
choices.microInsight: Shielding buys time; follow-up closes the loop.

choices.label: Work through the chaos and avoid the conversation.
choices.result: The day is stressful. The same error may repeat.
choices.microInsight: Avoiding the conversation avoids the fix.

scenarios.title: Colleague Questions Your Call in Front of the Patient
scenarios.context: A team member disagrees with your clinical judgment and raises it in the room. You notice a pull to assert authority. The moment is whether to correct in front of the patient or keep unity and discuss later.

choices.label: Correct the colleague in front of the patient and restate your finding.
choices.result: Authority is clear. The patient may sense tension. The colleague may feel diminished.
choices.microInsight: Winning in the room can cost cohesion.

choices.label: Acknowledge the question, state your finding briefly, suggest discussing criteria after the visit.
choices.result: The patient sees a unified team. Dialogue is deferred to a better time.
choices.microInsight: Unity in the room; alignment in private.

choices.label: Invite their view, then explain your rationale and confirm the plan.
choices.result: The patient sees collaboration. You still own the final call. Trust can grow.
choices.microInsight: Including the team can strengthen leadership.

choices.label: Say you will review the chart later and defer.
choices.result: The patient may lose confidence. The issue is postponed.
choices.microInsight: Deferring in the room can look like indecision.

scenarios.title: Manager Pushes for Higher Production
scenarios.context: The manager wants higher daily production and suggests adding cosmetic treatment. You notice discomfort. The moment is whether to state your boundary or avoid the conversation.

choices.label: State that you will not recommend treatment that is not clinically indicated.
choices.result: Your line is clear. The manager may push back or respect it.
choices.microInsight: A clear no protects integrity.

choices.label: Schedule a private meeting to discuss mission, metrics, and where you draw the line.
choices.result: Space is created to align on values. Metrics can be reframed.
choices.microInsight: Mission and metrics can align when discussed.

choices.label: Go along once or twice to keep the peace.
choices.result: Short-term peace may blur the line over time.
choices.microInsight: Small compromises can normalize pressure.

choices.label: Avoid the manager and focus on your own schedule.
choices.result: Tension remains. The conversation is deferred.
choices.microInsight: Avoidance does not protect integrity.

scenarios.title: Repeated Sterilization Log Errors
scenarios.context: Logs show repeated sterilization mistakes. A pack failed a check. You notice concern for safety. The moment is whether to discipline first or retrain and add a system check.

choices.label: Issue a formal warning and require signed acknowledgment of protocol.
choices.result: Compliance is emphasized. The person may feel singled out. Future errors may be hidden.
choices.microInsight: Discipline alone may not fix system or skill.

choices.label: Schedule retraining and add a double-check step; no public blame.
choices.result: Process is strengthened. Accountability is clear without shaming. Safety can improve.
choices.microInsight: Systems and training often reduce errors more than blame.

choices.label: Do sterilization yourself for a period and observe where it breaks down.
choices.result: You see the workflow and can fix root causes. The assistant sees your commitment.
choices.microInsight: Seeing the process reveals gaps.

choices.label: Mention it lightly and hope they improve.
choices.result: The person may not take it seriously. Risk remains.
choices.microInsight: Minimizing safety issues increases risk.

scenarios.title: Negative Online Review About Wait Time
scenarios.context: A patient left a negative review about waiting. It is public. You notice a pull to defend or correct the details. The moment is how you respond—public reply, private outreach, or no response.

choices.label: Reply publicly with an apology and commitment to improve.
choices.result: The public sees accountability. The patient may soften. Feedback is acknowledged.
choices.microInsight: A thoughtful reply can build trust.

choices.label: Reach out privately first, then post a short public thank-you for feedback.
choices.result: The patient may feel heard. The public sees a response. Both channels are used.
choices.microInsight: Private contact plus public acknowledgment often works.

choices.label: Post a factual correction to the review.
choices.result: Facts may be clarified. The patient may feel dismissed. Readers may see defensiveness.
choices.microInsight: Correcting facts can feel like invalidating experience.

choices.label: Do not respond.
choices.result: The review stands. No signal is sent that feedback matters.
choices.microInsight: No response is often read as not caring.

scenarios.title: Patient Asks for a Refund After Completed Treatment
scenarios.context: A patient requests a refund after treatment is complete. Policy does not support it. You notice a pull to say no quickly or to avoid conflict. The moment is how you deliver the boundary and what you offer next.

choices.label: State policy: no refunds after treatment.
choices.result: The boundary is clear. The patient may feel unheard. Relationship may be damaged.
choices.microInsight: Policy alone rarely repairs trust.

choices.label: Acknowledge their request, state the policy, and offer one clear next step (e.g., payment plan, future discount).
choices.result: The patient hears the limit and a path forward. Trust has a chance to hold.
choices.microInsight: Boundary plus option often preserves relationship.

choices.label: Say you will ask the manager and get back to them.
choices.result: Expectation may be set that an exception is possible. Clarity is delayed.
choices.microInsight: Deferring can raise false hope.

choices.label: Offer a partial refund to avoid conflict.
choices.result: Conflict may be reduced short-term. Policy precedent may be set.
choices.microInsight: One exception can become the new norm.

scenarios.title: New Team Member Is Quiet in Meetings
scenarios.context: A new team member rarely speaks in meetings. You notice a pull to call them out or to leave them alone. The moment is whether to create a low-pressure opening or assume they will speak when ready.

choices.label: Call on them by name and ask for their view.
choices.result: They may contribute. They may also feel put on the spot.
choices.microInsight: Direct ask can help or increase pressure.

choices.label: After the meeting, ask them one-on-one if there is something they would have added.
choices.result: They may share in safety. You signal their input matters. No public pressure.
choices.microInsight: Private invite often increases future participation.

choices.label: Leave them alone; they will speak when ready.
choices.result: No pressure is added. They may never feel invited. Norm may stay the same.
choices.microInsight: Waiting can be read as not needing their input.

choices.label: Suggest to the group that everyone should speak at least once.
choices.result: A norm is set. The new member may comply or feel more pressure.
choices.microInsight: Group rules can help or feel generic.

scenarios.title: Supply Order Is Wrong and Affects Tomorrow
scenarios.context: A critical supply order is wrong and will affect tomorrow’s schedule. You notice blame forming. The moment is how you address the error and what you do next.

choices.label: Tell the team who made the error and that it must not happen again.
choices.result: Responsibility is assigned. The person may feel shamed. Future errors may be hidden.
choices.microInsight: Blame often reduces reporting.

choices.label: Focus on fixing tomorrow: reorder, borrow, or reschedule. Then review the ordering process with the person privately.
choices.result: The day is secured. Learning happens without public shame. Process can improve.
choices.microInsight: Fix first, then learn, preserves trust.

choices.label: Take over ordering yourself from now on.
choices.result: Control increases. The other person loses a chance to learn. Bottleneck is created.
choices.microInsight: Taking over can block growth.

choices.label: Hope someone else fixes it.
choices.result: Tomorrow may be disrupted. No clear ownership.
choices.microInsight: Avoiding leaves the problem unsolved.

scenarios.title: Patient Requests a Different Provider Next Time
scenarios.context: A patient asks to see a different provider at their next visit. You notice a pull to take it personally or to dismiss it. The moment is how you respond and what you do with the information.

choices.label: Say that is fine and note it in the chart. Do not ask why.
choices.result: The request is honored. No feedback is gathered. Chance to learn is missed.
choices.microInsight: Accommodating without asking misses data.

choices.label: Honor the request and ask briefly if there is something the team could do better.
choices.result: The patient is respected. Optional feedback is gathered. No pressure.
choices.microInsight: Inviting feedback often yields useful information.

choices.label: Ask why; you want to understand.
choices.result: You may learn. The patient may feel put on the spot or defensive.
choices.microInsight: Probing can feel like justification-seeking.

choices.label: Try to change their mind and keep them with you.
choices.result: The patient may feel unheard. Trust may drop. They may still leave.
choices.microInsight: Persuading against a clear request often backfires.

recovery_quick_check_5.title: Recovery Quick Check
recovery_quick_check_5.description: Five short, repeatable prompts for after a run or as a daily check. Notice and name only; no diagnosis or emotional labeling.

items.prompt: Notice what you feel in your body right now. Name one sensation (e.g., tightness, warmth, ease) without judging it.
Name one thing you did in the last hour that was in your control. Keep it to a single, concrete action.
Name one thing you would do the same if this situation happened again, and one thing you would do differently. Keep each to one sentence.
Notice your next breath. Inhale once, then exhale once. No change needed—just observe.
Name one small next step you can take in the next 10 minutes. Keep it specific and doable.
